name: hydrogen production, steam methane reforming | hydrogen, gaseous, low pressure | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/29831/documentation

This activity models the production of 1 kg of gaseous hydrogen, at 25 bar, from steam methane refoming of natural gas. This process does not include further compression or liquefaction of hydrogen after its production. This dataset does not cover any carbon dioxide capture and storage function. ;;In steam reforming, methane is treated with steam to form carbon monoxide and hydrogen.The yield of the hydrogen production is increased further by a water gas shift reaction, where the formed carbon monoxide  reacts with water to form carbon dioxide and hydrogen. In this process, full water gas shift is assumed and therefore no synthesis gas (mixture of CO and H2) is co-produced, Subseqently, the raw hydrogen is purified in a PSA unit. The endothermic reforming reaction requires heat in the form of high-pressure steam as input. This heat is provided by an external natural gas industrial furnace, where natural gas is burned resulting in the usual emissions to air from burning natural gas. As such, natural gas is usually used both as feedstock to the reaction and as fuel for the furnace. The natural gas origin (country or mix) is important with regards to the sum of methane emissions over the whole natural gas supply chain. The users of this dataset are asked to carefully consider a change of the natural gas supplying dataset if this seems to be appropriate.;In China, about 20% of hydrogen is produced by steam methane reforming. ;Hydrogen is an inorganic substance with a CAS no. : 001333-74-0. It is called 'molecular hydrogen' under IUPAC naming and its molecular formula is: H2. It is gaseous and it has no odour. The substance is modelled as a pure substance. On a consumer level, is used in the following products: fuels and related products, water treatment products. On industrial sites, the substance is used for the manufacture of products in the following sectors: Fuels and fuel additives, functional fluids (closed systems), intermediates, laboratory chemicals, odour agents, oxidizing/reducing agents, processing aids, specific to petroleum production.;This dataset was recontextualised from the European dataset.;References:;Häussinger P., Lohmüller R., Watson A. M. (2012): Hydrogen, Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.;Antonini C., Treyer K., Streb A., van der Spek M., Bauer C., Mazzotti M. (2020): Hydrogen production from natural gas and biomethane with carbon capture and storage – A techno-environmental analysis, Sustainable Energy Fuels.

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process.

Production of hydrogen at a pressure of 25 bar including materials, energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/352:Manufacture of gas; distribution of gaseous fuels through mains/3520:Manufacture of gas; distribution of gaseous fuels through mains

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This activity originates from literature data, based on robust process simulation, for steam methane reforming published in 2020. The material and energy inputs reflect well the production technology and not expected to change significantly over time.;References:;Antonini C., Treyer K., Streb A., van der Spek M., Bauer C., Mazzotti M. (2020): Hydrogen production from natural gas and biomethane with carbon capture and storage – A techno-environmental analysis, Sustainable Energy Fuels.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This activity originates from literature data, based on robust process simulation, for steam methane reforming without a specific geographical region. The material and energy inputs reflect well the production technology and are, therefore, considered to be valid for the chosen geography.;References:;Antonini C., Treyer K., Streb A., van der Spek M., Bauer C., Mazzotti M. (2020): Hydrogen production from natural gas and biomethane with carbon capture and storage – A techno-environmental analysis, Sustainable Energy Fuels.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: In steam methane reforming, methane reacts with steam to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide. In a first step, the natural gas feedstock is desulfurized and pre-treated with some steam to break down higher hydrocarbons into methane. The steam to carbon ratio at the pre-reformer inlet is set to 2.6. The pre-treated feedstock is then led into the main reforming reactor, and methane is coverted into hydrogen and carbon monoxide. This reaction is endothermic (consumes energy), and therefore heat is provided by an external furnace (often fuelled with natural gas). The hydrogen yield is improved by a water gas shift section, where a part of the formed carbon monoxide reacts with water to produce carbon dioxide and hydrogen. In this process, full water gas shift is assumed and therefore no synthesis gas (mixture of CO and H2) is co-produced, Technical details of the SMR plant which serves as model for this dataset are presented in Antonini, Treyer et al. (2020). Hydrogen production from natural gas and biomethane with carbon capture and storage - A techno-environmmental analysis. Sustainable Energy & Fuels.;SMR: CH4 + H2O --> 3 H2 + CO;WGS: CO + H2O --> H2 + CO2;Carbon dioxide is not captured in this modelling, it exits the plant with the flue gas from the furnace.;The high pressure steam required in steam methane reforming as well as the water gas shift is co-generated by heat integration. The excess steam is sent to a turbine to genereate electricity, which can be used to run utilities in the plant. If there is a surplus of electricity, it is sold to be fed to the grid.;The catalysts used in the desulfurization is ZnO, reforming needs a Nickel based catalyst and the water gas shift is conducted on Fe-Cr and Cu-Zn beds.;The purity of the produced hydrogen is at least 99.97%.;The electricity and heat needed in all processes is produced internally from natural gas. In the technical modelling of Antonini/Treyer et al. an amount of excess electricity results from this internal electricity production, it is assumed to be sold to the grid.;References:;Antonini C., Treyer K., Streb A., van der Spek M., Bauer C., Mazzotti M. (2020): Hydrogen production from natural gas and biomethane with carbon capture and storage – A techno-environmental analysis, Sustainable Energy Fuels.;Häussinger P., Lohmüller R., Watson A. M. (2012): Hydrogen, Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
This dataset is based on literature data. The technology is representative for steam reforming Globally and regionalised through the input feedstocks.
The emissions to air stem from burning natural gas in the furnace. These emissions in kg per MJ natural gas burned are extrapolated from the activity "heat production, natural gas, at industrial furnace > 100kW, Europe without Switzerland" (ecoinvent version v3.9.1, 2022), with 1.0526 MJ natural gas burned per MJ heat. The CO2 emissions from that dataset are omitted, as CO2 emissions have been modelled separately in Antonini, Treyer et al. 2020.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Data obtained from the literature. 
References:
Antonini C., Treyer K., Streb A., van der Spek M., Bauer C., Mazzotti M. (2020): Hydrogen production from natural gas and biomethane with carbon capture and storage - A techno-environmental analysis, Sustainable Energy Fuels.

exchanges.description: Emission from burning natural gas used as a fuel in the production process. These emissions have been calculated as a proxy based on the dataset “heat production, natural gas, at industrial furnace >100kW, Europe without Switzerland”, ecoinvent version 3.9.1 (2022) cut-off. In this activity, emissions in kg per MJ heat produced are shown, which were turned into kg of emissions per MJ natural gas burned. The carbon dioxide emissions of the above mentioned dataset have been discarded, as these are calculated for the specific case of hydrogen production.

exchanges.description:
The pre-treated feedstock is led into the main reforming reactor, and methane is coverted into hydrogen and carbon monoxide. This step requires a Nickel based catalyst.
Nickel is used as a proxy, but the energy consumption for producing NiO is not considered.

See more in Antonini C., Treyer K., Streb A., van der Spek M., Bauer C., Mazzotti M. (2020): Hydrogen production from natural gas and biomethane with carbon capture and storage - A techno-environmental analysis, Sustainable Energy Fuels.

exchanges.description: Emission from burning natural gas used as a fuel in the production process. These emissions have been calculated as a proxy based on the dataset “heat production, natural gas, at industrial furnace >100kW, Europe without Switzerland”, ecoinvent version 3.9.1 (2022) cut-off. In this activity, emissions in kg per MJ heat produced are shown, which were turned into kg of emissions per MJ natural gas burned. The carbon dioxide emissions of the above mentioned dataset have been discarded, as these are calculated for the specific case of hydrogen production.

The hydrogen yield is improved by a water gas shift section, where a part of the formed carbon monoxide reacts with water to produce carbon dioxide and hydrogen. The water gas shift is conducted on Fe-Cr and Cu-Zn beds at high- and low-temperatures, respectively. Portafer (ferric oxide) represents part of the materials that make up these beds.

See more in Antonini C., Treyer K., Streb A., van der Spek M., Bauer C., Mazzotti M. (2020): Hydrogen production from natural gas and biomethane with carbon capture and storage - A techno-environmental analysis, Sustainable Energy Fuels.

In steam methane reforming, methane is reacted with steam to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide.

WGS: CO + H2O --> H2 + CO2

Calculated value. This value is estimated based on the CO2 output of this dataset to ensure the mass balance and the completeness of the dataset. It was assumed that all oxygen in CO2 originates from air.
These emissions of CO2 stem from the flue gas of the natural gas furnace and from the reforming of the natural gas feedstock and the water gas shift of syngas to hydrogen.

Initially, sulfur and a wide variety of sulfur compounds are removed from the natural gas feedstock, prior to the reforming step, in a treatment stage. Notably, the presence of sulfur decreases the lifetime of most metal catalysts, and thus, an effective treatment of the feed gas is vital. The catalysts used in the desulfurization is ZnO.


See more in Antonini C., Treyer K., Streb A., van der Spek M., Bauer C., Mazzotti M. (2020): Hydrogen production from natural gas and biomethane with carbon capture and storage - A techno-environmental analysis, Sustainable Energy Fuels.
